newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan sets date for delayed census.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan sets date for delayed census.

text.p: Pakistan on Wednesday decided to hold a long-delayed census of the fast-rising population.
A government statement said Pakistan's fifth population census would be held between October 18 and 31.
Pakistan's population, growing at an estimated 2.77 percent a year, is officially put at around 135 million against 84 million recorded in 1981.
A census was due in 1991 but was postponed several times because of law and order problems in the southern province of Sindh and bad weather.
Punjab province, the most populous, had expressed fears the other three provinces could over-count their populations and undercut Punjab's share of federal jobs and funds.

Legislators in the tense southwestern province of Baluchistan feared the predominantly Pushtun refugees from neighbouring Afghanistan, many of whom carry local identity cards, could be counted as Pakistanis.
Pakistan was host to more than three million Afghan refugees at the height of the 14-year civil war in Afghanistan. Most returned home after the mujahideen guerrillas took power there in 1992.
